etymology.description: two hands 廾(廾) (gǒng, 'two hands') holding an object, perhaps an instrument from a ritual originally similar to 夲(夲) (tuō, 'root') -> final form 奏(奏) (zòu, 'perform')
etymology.interpretation: The character 奏(奏) (zòu, 'perform') symbolizes two hands holding a musical object used in a ritual, highlighting the connection to ceremonial performances. This reflects its role in traditional sacrificial music performances.

examples.chinese: 乐团今晚将在音乐厅奏一首新曲(樂團今晚將在音樂廳奏一首新曲)。
examples.pinyin: Yuètuán jīnwǎn jiāng zài yīnyuètīng zòu yī shǒu xīnqǔ.
examples.english: The orchestra will perform a new piece tonight.

examples.chinese: 他每次上台都会全情投入奏自己的作品(他每次上臺都會全情投入奏自己的作品)。
examples.pinyin: Tā měi cì shàngtái dōu huì quánqíng tóurù zòu zìjǐ de zuòpǐn.
examples.english: He always puts his heart into performing his own pieces every time he goes on stage.

examples.chinese: 琴师精心调音后(琴師精心調音後)，开始奏乐(開始奏樂)。
examples.pinyin: Qínshī jīngxīn tiáoyīn hòu, kāishǐ zòu yuè.
examples.english: After the pianist finely tuned the instrument, he began to perform music.
